documentType: autopsy report and related medical examiner records
summary: This document is a collection of official medical examiner records related to the death of Jeffrey Epstein, released in response to a DOJ OIG request. It includes the autopsy report, toxicology reports, neuropathology report, and anthropology report, all concluding the cause of death was suicide by hanging. The documents detail the forensic findings and certify the records as official business records. This document is the New York City Office of Chief Medical Examiner's case file for Jeffrey Epstein, detailing the investigation into his death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It includes the death certificate worksheet, autopsy request forms, scene investigation report, and case notes documenting communication with family and law enforcement. This document contains internal case notes from the New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner regarding the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It details the receipt of evidence, autopsy procedures, coordination with law enforcement, and family involvement, including the presence of a privately retained pathologist to observe the autopsy. This document contains the official Notice of Death for Jeffrey Epstein, a Clinical Summary Worksheet, a Mortuary Release Document, and excerpts from the Metropolitan Correctional Center's Daily Lieutenant's Logs covering the days before and after his death. It records the circumstances of his death at the MCC, his transport to the hospital, and the subsequent release of his body. This document contains a Bureau of Prisons incident report detailing Jeffrey Epstein's self-mutilation/suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, a detailed timeline of events surrounding his death on August 10, 2019, and related memoranda and chain of custody logs for his personal effects. It provides a minute-by-minute account of the response to his death and the subsequent investigation. This document is a series of photo sheets from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York documenting the scene of inmate Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. It records the incident time, location within the facility (Z4), and subsequent photographs taken at the scene and at an outside hospital.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The individual who died. The document records his death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and the subsequent release of his body.

connections.description: Dr. Roman performed the autopsy on Jeffrey Epstein's body.
Dr. Sampson, as Chief Medical Examiner, delegated authority to Yvelisse Matias to certify OCME records.
Dr. Graham, as First Deputy Chief Medical Examiner, reviewed the autopsy report prepared by Dr. Roman.
Dr. Folkerth performed the neuropathology examination with Dr. Roman in attendance.
Dr. Soler analyzed the hyoid and larynx specimens removed by Dr. Roman during the autopsy.
Mark Epstein is identified as the brother and next of kin of Jeffrey Epstein.
Stacey Richman is identified as the attorney for Jeffrey Epstein's family, communicating with the medical examiner on their behalf.
Medical examiner Roman communicated directly with Mark Epstein regarding autopsy procedures, cause of death, and the family's request for an independent observer.
Schultz, from OCME, was present at the death scene with FBI Special Agents and later met with the FBI to review surveillance video.
Tartaglione was Epstein's cellmate in July 2019 and alerted guards to Epstein's prior suicide attempt.
Reyes was Epstein's cellmate in the SHU until his release on August 9, 2019, the day before Epstein's death.
Liggio was accompanied by Schultz, the Deputy Director, for the scene investigation at the MCC.
Mark Epstein is identified as the brother and next of kin of the decedent, Jeffrey Epstein.
Mark Epstein, the brother, privately retained pathologist Dr. Michael Baden to observe Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy.
OCME investigator Liggio was in contact with Mark Epstein regarding the autopsy and the private pathologist request.
Schultz and Czevekus, both OCME officials, discussed the case as part of the investigation response.
Medical Examiner Roman spoke with an FBI liaison detective about the need for evidence (clothing, ligature) for the death investigation.
Stephen Schubert, the funeral director, was authorized by Mark Epstein to receive Jeffrey Epstein's body.
Nicholas Schultz was assigned as an investigator and MLI for Epstein's death case.
Sheril Pitters accepted the Medical Examiner case for Epstein's death.
Were cellmates; Reyes departed for court on the morning before Epstein's death.
Epstein was a defendant in a case before Judge Berman, who was notified of his death.

events.title: Autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Autopsy performed by Dr. Kristin Roman on the body of Jeffrey Epstein, commencing at 9:21 AM at the Manhattan Mortuary.

events.title: Neuropathology Examination
events.description: Macroscopic neuropathology examination performed by Dr. Rebecca Folkerth, with Dr. Kristin Roman in attendance, finding a normal brain and spinal cord.

events.title: Anthropology Report Completion
events.description: Forensic anthropologist Dr. Angela Soler issues report detailing fractures to the hyoid and thyroid cartilage from Epstein's remains.

events.title: Toxicology Report Issued
events.description: NMS Labs issues toxicology report showing no detection of ethanol, drugs, or synthetic cannabinoids in femoral blood samples.

events.title: DOJ OIG Request for Medical Examiner File
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General writes to the NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner requesting the complete case file on Epstein's death.

events.title: Certification of OCME Records
events.description: Yvelisse Matias certifies the attached medical examiner records as true and accurate copies of the original documents.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive, hanging by the neck in his cell (#220) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at approximately 06:33 hours. He was pronounced dead at New York Presbyterian Lower Manhattan Hospital at 07:36 AM.

events.title: Prior Suicide Attempt by Epstein
events.description: Epstein attempted suicide by hanging in his cell using a 'loose homemade noose' made from a torn orange bedsheet. He was found by his cellmate Tartaglione and corrections officers.

events.title: Autopsy and Independent Observer Request
events.description: An autopsy was performed on Jeffrey Epstein. His brother, Mark Epstein, requested and was granted permission to have an independent forensic pathologist observe the autopsy under specific conditions set by OCME.

events.title: Review of Surveillance Video with FBI
events.description: Dr. Kristin Roman and Nicholas Schultz from OCME met with the FBI at 26 Federal Plaza to review a short, blurry surveillance video from the MCC dated August 10, 2019. The video did not show Epstein's cell or tier.

events.title: Disclosure of Cause and Manner of Death
events.description: Dr. Kristin Roman had a detailed phone conversation with Mark Epstein and family attorney Stacey Richman to discuss the cause and manner of death before amending the death certificate.

events.title: Death and Initial Notification
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein found deceased at Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC); OCME notified and begins death investigation.

events.title: Autopsy Performed with Private Observer
events.description: Autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein is performed at OCME. Dr. Michael Baden, a private pathologist retained by Mark Epstein, observes the procedure after being swabbed for DNA.

events.title: Prior Suicide Attempt
events.description: Documents received from MCC focus chiefly on a suicide attempt incident involving Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Scene Investigation at MCC
events.description: OCME investigators (Schultz and Liggio) visit cell 220 at MCC. Scans of the cell are performed but cannot be uploaded immediately.

events.title: Family Consent and Request
events.description: Mark Epstein, the brother, gives no objection to the autopsy but requests his privately retained pathologist be allowed to observe. Dr. Graham approves the request.

events.title: Fingerprint Identification
events.description: Fingerprints from the decedent are processed, resulting in a hit with NYSID 048148790, confirming identity.

events.title: Receipt of Additional Records
events.description: Additional hospital or medical records are received from the NYP Medical Correspondence Unit and from James Saunders, Esq. of the FDNY.

events.title: Medical Emergency and Transport
events.description: At 6:33 AM, a medical emergency was announced for Epstein. EMS arrived at 6:43 AM and departed with him to the hospital at 7:10 AM while CPR continued.

events.title: Death Investigation Initiated
events.description: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner was notified and investigators (Schultz, Pitters) were assigned. The case was flagged as 'High Profile'.

events.title: Release of Epstein's Body
events.description: Epstein's body was released from the Office of Chief Medical Examiner to funeral director Stephen Schubert of Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, authorized by his brother Mark Epstein.

events.title: MCC Operations Prior to Death
events.description: The MCC log notes routine operations, inmates on psych observation, a fire alarm system malfunction, and a lockdown. The beginning count was 757 inmates.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Attempt in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 am, inmate Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself in SHU Cell 124 using an orange homemade rope. He was found by staff and his cellmate Tartaglione, was breathing but unresponsive, and was revived.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead in Cell
events.description: At 6:33 am, a body alarm was activated in the SHU. Staff found Jeffrey Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR was initiated, EMS transported him to Beekman Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 7:36 am.

events.title: Epstein's Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein had attorney visits throughout the day and was provided a social call at 7:00 pm, during which he called his mother. Staff reported he was in good spirits.

events.title: Notification and Investigation Initiation
events.description: Following Epstein's death, numerous entities were notified including the FBI, AUSA, Judge Berman, OIG, and next of kin. The FBI and OIG arrived at MCC to investigate.

events.title: Remains Transported to Morgue
events.description: Epstein's remains were prepared at New York Presbyterian Hospital, transported to the hospital morgue, and later transferred to the city morgue by the Office of the City Medical Examiner.

events.title: Evidence Collection
events.description: Computer hard drives were removed from the SHU and replaced. Epstein's personal effects, including medications, books, mail, and a bible, were logged into evidence.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York at 6:33 AM. The incident is classified as an inmate suicide.

events.title: Photographic Documentation of Scene
events.description: Lieutenants and/or Special Investigative Section personnel took photographs of the suicide scene in cell location Z4 at 6:49 AM, and later at an outside hospital.

keyFacts: The official cause of Jeffrey Epstein's death is listed as 'HANGING' and the manner of death as 'SUICIDE (HANGED SELF)'.
The autopsy found a ligature furrow on the neck, fractures of the thyroid cartilage and left hyoid cornua, petechial hemorrhages, and injuries consistent with resuscitation attempts.
Toxicology reports on femoral blood, vitreous fluid, and other specimens detected no ethanol, drugs (including benzoylecgonine, opiates, benzodiazepines, fentanyl), or synthetic cannabinoids.
A neuropathology report found Epstein's brain and spinal cord to be normal, with a brain weight of 1520g.
An anthropology report confirmed fractures to the left greater horn of the hyoid bone and both superior horns of the thyroid cartilage.
Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell (Cell #220, Tier L, SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on the morning of August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at the hospital at 7:36 AM.
Epstein had attempted suicide by hanging in his cell just weeks earlier, on July 23, 2019, using a torn bedsheet.
At the time of his death, Epstein was alone in his cell; his cellmate, Reyes, had been released from court the previous day.
Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, requested and was granted permission for an independent forensic pathologist to observe the official autopsy conducted by the NYC OCME.

The OCME investigator's report notes the presence of FBI Special Agents at the death scene and subsequent collaboration to review surveillance footage, which was blurry and did not show Epstein's cell.
Jeffrey Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, had no objection to the autopsy but requested a privately retained pathologist, Dr. Michael Baden, to observe the procedure.
DNA swabs were collected from autopsy observer Dr. Michael Baden on August 11, 2019.
OCME investigators documented a prior suicide attempt by Epstein on July 23, 2019, based on records received from the MCC.
The ligature used in the death was at the OCME DNA building and had not been examined by the medical examiner at the time of the initial notes.
The case was treated as high-profile by the OCME, affecting procedures like X-ray access and communication with external organizations like Live On NY.
Jeffrey Epstein died on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. He was found unresponsive in cell 106-220 in Unit 9 South.
The official Notice of Death lists the manner of death as 'Undetermined' and notes the case was immediately treated as 'High Profile' by investigators.
Epstein's body was released to the Frank E. Campbell funeral home on August 11, 2019, authorized by his brother, Mark Epstein.
MCC logs from August 9-10, 2019, show routine operations and several other inmates on psychological observation or in dry cells, providing context for the facility's conditions.
A note in the death report indicates a request from an organization (Live On NY) to place a hold on the body was denied because the case was high profile.
Jeffrey Epstein attempted suicide by hanging in his prison cell on July 23, 2019, using an orange homemade rope, but was revived.
Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the MCC on August 10, 2019, at 6:33 am and was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 am.
On the evening before his death (August 9), Epstein was reported to be in 'good spirits' during a social call where he spoke to his mother.
Immediately after his death, computer hard drives were removed from the Special Housing Unit and his personal belongings were seized as evidence.
The FBI and the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) were notified and arrived on-site to investigate on the day of Epstein's death.
Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, at 6:33 AM while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
The incident occurred in cell location Z4 within the facility.
Official photographs of the scene were taken by prison personnel at 6:49 AM, approximately 16 minutes after the incident was recorded.
Additional photographs were later taken at an outside hospital, indicating Epstein's body was transported there.
The document is a formal, repetitive record of the incident and subsequent evidence collection by the correctional facility's Lieutenant's Office and Special Investigative Section.
